entry.title: Twitter's headquarters building (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Twitter's headquarters building (pictured) in San Francisco was built as a trade center for furniture wholesalers in 1937?

entry.title: published posthumously (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that more than 60 scientific papers authored by mathematician Paul Erdős were published posthumously?

entry.title: Echte Wagner (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that an album of collectible cards from the German margarine brand Echte Wagner in 1930 presented a vision of the future that incorporated concepts such as wireless personal phones with screens?

entry.title: Sandy Liang (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the New York City-based fashion label Sandy Liang is inspired by grandmothers in Chinatown, and often features Liang's own grandmother as a model?

entry.title: Campanile (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Campanile, a bell tower in Portmeirion, north Wales, was built in 1928 using stone from a nearby 12th-century castle?

entry.title: Adam W. Oberlin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Adam W. Oberlin, the 1917 Republican nominee to be the mayor of Canton, Ohio, went missing and was found seven months later working as a carpenter in Norfolk, Virginia?

entry.title: Biblioteca Gabriel García Márquez (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 2023 the IFLA named the Biblioteca Gabriel García Márquez the "best new public library in the world"?

entry.title: merry widows (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that merry widows like soft bottoms?
